text: This is a download from BBC Learning English to find out more, visit our website.
Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Aliceâ€¦
speaker: Alice

text: And I'm Neil, so Alice, what do you see when you look at me?
Oh well, um, male. Caucasian, early 40s, short, urban hair,
bushye eyebrows, thin lips.
Ah, okay. So that's how you see me.
It sounds like a police report, I'm not sure I like your observation about thin lips.
Caucasian means white, skinned and European, by the way.
speaker: Alice

text: Mmm, and today, this show is about identity, who or what a person is.
And the way people see us forms part of our sense of identity,
speaker: identityethnic

text: while another part comes from our ethnic or racial identity.
So my question for you today, Neil, is what percentage of the UK population
describe themselves as ethnically mixed?
Is it a 0.9%?
speaker: wear my heart on my sleeve

text: Okay, I think that it's a 0.9%.
Hmm, well, we'll find out if you got the answer right or wrong later on in the show.
Now, Neil, you are, of course, many more things than my physical description of you.
speaker: Neil

text: I'm glad to hear that.
speaker: Neil

text: And it's true that until you actually hear somebody speak,
there are lots of things you can't know about them.
For example, which country they're from, what language they speak.
Hmm, yes. So, looking at me, what would you say, Neil?
I would say, Alas, that you're a typical English rose.
Oh, thanks, Neil.
And English rose describes an attractive girl with a pale, delicate complexion,
speaker: Neil

text: or skin colour.
But you can't actually tell where a person is from, by the way, they look.
Yes, I suppose you're right.
speaker: Neil

text: I have a friend who also looks very English like you,
but she's a real ethnic mix.
Her dad's German and her mum's Brazilian.
Well, let's hear from New York City Actress and Playwright Sarah Jones
talking about her complicated ethnicity.
My family on my dad's side, my grandparents, are from the South.
speaker: Sarah Jones, actress and playwright, New York City

text: There's some Caribbean in there, Black Americans from the south and the Caribbean.
And then on my mother's side, there are people from the Caribbean,
from Ireland, but, you know, Irish American, German American.
People would ask me if I was adopted when they saw my mother's white skin.
She's actually mixed, but she's white from a distance.
And I'm Black from a distance.
Sarah Jones there. Well, Sarah has family from all over the world.
I suppose the United States and New York City, especially, is a real melting pot.
That's right. And melting pot describes a society made from people of different countries
speaker: melting pot

text: who live together and create a new shared culture.
And people think Sarah is adopted or raised by parents who aren't biologically hers,
because she looks so different to her mum.
But I expect Sarah sees herself as American. New York is where she was born and raised.
speaker: Alice

text: That's right, but her grandparents weren't.
Do you think you'd change when you go and live in another country with people different to you?
Yes, I do. My name is a Turkish, but they've lived in England for 45 years,
so they've integrated into our culture.
speaker: Alice

text: They enjoy English things like our TV soap operas,
cooking turkey at Christmas and drinking tea with milk.
And to integrate means to join a group of people and often involves changing your habits and
customs. Yes, okay. So, Neil, to what extent does the way other people see us actually change us?
Let's listen to Julian Bajini, a writer and philosopher here in the UK, and find out what he thinks.
It seems very evident that our sense of self isn't something that comes entirely from within.
speaker: Alice

text: And of course, we're affected by the way other people see us.
And that's one of the most formative things in creating our sense of identity.
I mean, I think it's kind of a two-way process that's ongoing.
In our sense of who we are, is always a response in part to how other people see us.
So, Julian Bajini believes the way other people see us is formative in creating our sense of identity or who we are.
And formative means important for the development of something.
speaker: formative

text: Hmm, so if enough people see you as an English rose, you might start to see yourself as an English rose,
even if you aren't ethnically English.
I'm not so sure. The friend I talked about earlier, she comes across as much more Brazilian than English
speaker: Neil

text: in the way she behaves. She doesn't have the famous English reserve,
but you never know it by looking at her.
And reserve means hiding what you're thinking or feeling.
I think I'm guilty of English reserve. How about you, Neil?
No, I think I wear my heart on my sleeve, Alice, which means I make my feelings clear.
Okay, I think it's time for the answer to today's quiz question.
Oh, good. Fair enough. I asked you what percentage of the UK population
described themselves as ethnically mixed. Is it A0.9%
B5.9% or C9%
And I said A0.9%
Yes, and you were on the money today, Neil. Well done.
speaker: Neil

text: Where are you?
According to a survey conducted by the BBC in 2011,
when asked about their own ethnic origins,
0.9% of the UK population said they were mixed race.
Although it's thought that the real figure is 2% or more.
Now, could you remind us of the words we heard today, Neil?
Sure, they are Caucasian, identity, ethnic, English rose,
complexion, melting pot, adopted, integrate,
formative, reserve, wear your heart on your sleeve.
And that's the end of today's 6 Minute English.
speaker: Neil

text: Don't forget to join us again soon.
Meanwhile, visit our website:
speaker: Neil

text: bbclearningenglish.com,
where you'll find guides to grammar, exercises,
videos and articles to read and improve your English.
Goodbye. Bye-bye.
